arca.arq package

ARQ is an easy-to-use Python library for creating cryptographic schemes that handle aggregate range queries (sum, minimum, median, and mode) over encrypted datasets. Using ARQ, structures from the plaintext data management community may be easily unified with existing structured encryption primitives to produce schemes with defined, provable leakage profiles and security guarantees.

The ARQ library includes several constructions that handle various types of encrypted aggregate range queries. Most of the implemented schemes have constant asympototic query complexity in the worst-case.

The ARQ framework and associated schemes are described in more detail (with formal security definitions and proofs) in the paper “Time- and Space-Efficient Range Aggregate Queries on Encrypted Databases” by Zachary Espiritu, Evangelia Anna Markatou, and Roberto Tamassia. Our paper provides more details on the benefits of the ARQ framework in comparison to prior work, as well as formal leakage definitions and adaptive security proofs.

Example

from arca.arq import ARQ, Table, RangeQuery
from arca.arq.plaintext_schemes.sum import SumPrefix
from arca.ste.edx import SimpleEDX
from arca.ste.serializers import IntSerializer

# Make a Table:
table = Table.make([(0, 0), (1, 1), (2, 2), (3, 3)])

# Choose your aggregate scheme:
aggregate_scheme = SumPrefix()

# Choose an appropiate structured encryption scheme for the data
# structure output by your chosen aggregate scheme. SumPrefix
# outputs a Dict[int, int], so we can use the SimpleEDX scheme to
# encrypt the dictionary. Since the keys and values of the
# dictionary are integers, we can also set the serializers used by
# SimpleEDX to IntSerializer for both the keys and values:
eds_scheme = SimpleEDX(
   dx_key_serializer=IntSerializer(),
   dx_value_serializer=IntSerializer(),
)

# Instantiate the ARQ framework with your chosen aggregate scheme
# and structured encryption scheme:
arq_scheme = ARQ(
   aggregate_scheme=aggregate_scheme,
   eds_scheme=eds_scheme,
)

# In the setup phase (run on the client), generate a key and encrypt
# the table with the scheme:
key = arq_scheme.generate_key()
eds_serialized = arq_scheme.setup(key, table)

# Send the serialized encrypted index to the server, then unserialize
# it on the server-side:
eds = arq_scheme.load_eds(eds_serialized)

# In the query phase, the client makes a query (example: [0, 4)) and
# retrieves the result:
range_query = RangeQuery(start=0, end=4)
result = arq_scheme.query(key, table.domain, range_query, eds)
assert result == 6

generate_key() → bytes

Generates a key for use in setup().

Returns

a key

setup(key: bytes, table: Table) → bytes

Creates a new encrypted range aggregate index over the given Table with the given key.

Parameters

  • key¶ – the key to encrypt with

  • table¶ – the Table to compute the encrypted index over

Returns

the serialized encrypted index

load_eds(eds_serialized: bytes) → arca.arq.arq.EdsType

Deserializes the given encrypted data structure that was previously generated by setup().

Parameters

eds_serialized¶ – the serialized eds to load, as generated by setup()

Returns

the deserialized encrypted data structure

arca.arq.domain module

class Domain(start: int, end: int)

Bases: object

Represents the range of queryable values in a Table.

start: int

Start of the domain (inclusive).

end: int

End of the domain (exclusive).

size() → int

Returns the number of possible domain values. In other words, size = end - start.

Returns

the size of the Domain

class RangeAggregateQuerier

Bases: abc.ABC, Generic[arca.arq.range_aggregate_querier.DSQueryType, arca.arq.range_aggregate_querier.DSResponseType]

abstract query() → List[arca.arq.range_aggregate_querier.DSQueryType]

Corresponds to the \(\mathbb{Q}\) algorithm.

abstract resolve(responses: List[arca.arq.range_aggregate_querier.DSResponseType]) → Union[ResolveDone, ResolveContinue[arca.arq.range_aggregate_querier.DSQueryType]]

Corresponds to the \(\mathbb{R}\) algorithm.

arca.arq.range_aggregate_scheme module

class RangeAggregateScheme

Bases: abc.ABC, Generic[arca.arq.range_aggregate_scheme.DSType, arca.arq.range_aggregate_scheme.DSQueryType, arca.arq.range_aggregate_scheme.DSResponseType]

Interface corresponding to the plaintext aggregate range query scheme syntax \((\mathbb{S}, \mathbb{Q}, \mathbb{R})\) defined in [EMT22].

abstract setup(table: Table) → arca.arq.range_aggregate_scheme.DSType

Corresponds to the \(\mathbb{S}\) algorithm.

arca.arq.range_query module

class RangeQuery(start: int, end: int)

Bases: object

Represents a range query.

start: int

Start of the range (inclusive).

end: int

End of the range (exclusive).

length() → int

Returns the number of domain values contained within the query. In other words, length = end - start.

Returns

the length of the RangeQuery

arca.arq.table module

class Table(entries: Dict[int, List[int]], domain: Domain)

Bases: object

Represents a collection of records.

entries: Dict[int, List[int]]
domain: Domain
filter(domain_value: int) → List[int]

Returns all of the records with matching domain_value. The returned List is not in any defined order (only used to allow for duplicates).

Parameters

domain_value¶ – the domain value to filter for

Returns

a List of all records located at the particular domain_value

filter_range(range_query: RangeQuery) → List[int]

Returns all of the records contained in the given range_query. The returned List is not in any defined order (only used to allow for duplicates).

Parameters

range_query¶ – the range to filter over

Returns

a List of all records matching the filter
